repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Vilcanota Valley Rehabilitation and
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Vilcanota Valley
            Rehabilitation and Management Project for Peru were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk
            to development outcome was low or negligible, the Bank
            performance was moderately unsatisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was also moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the project attempted to address a broad
            range of multi-sectoral issues ranging from cultural
            heritage preservation to regional development and provision
            of basic infrastructure services. Addressing this complex
            range of themes required multiple institutions and large
            teams on both the Bank and the Government side.
            Participatory processes only contributed to the excessive
            scope and complexity of the original design. Some activities
            required coordination among several institutions at
            different government level, such as the revisions and
            approvals of the feasibility studies. Poor
            inter-institutional coordination and communication created
            delays and often contradicting messages to the consultant.
            The Bank team supported intensive training in procurement
            and financial management but this was not done early enough
            in the project cycle and resulted in large delays in
            disbursements. The decision to prior review all contracts
            adopted during the restructuring reduced procurement risk
            but also created substantial delays for the Borrower while
            waiting for Bank no objections.

repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Vilcanota Valley Rehabilitation and
            Management Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
This project paper concerns the
            restructuring of the Peru, Vilcanota Valley Rehabilitation
            and Management Project, and accompanying amendments to the
            project's legal documents. The changes are to: 1)
            transfer from the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Tourism
            (MINCETUR) to the Cusco Regional Government (GRC) the
            execution of several specific subcomponents; 2) streamline
            and simplify project implementation procedures; 3)
            reallocate funds among disbursement categories so as to
            better reflect modifications of certain project
            subcomponents; as a result, schedule one to the loan
            agreement has been modified to reflect adjustments to
            counterpart funds; 4) include changes in the nature of
            certain subcomponents to better fit expected outcomes and
            available funds, refocusing the project on a limited number
            of high-priority subcomponents; 5) strengthen institutional
            counterpart capacity for managing project fiduciary and
            safeguard responsibilities; 6) enhance Government ownership
            and create an additional accountability mechanism by
            introducing an inter-institutional Steering Committee; 7)
            modify the project's results framework and outcome
            indicators; and 8) extend the closing date by 24 months.

repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Vilcanota Valley Rehabilitation and
            Management Project : indigenous peoples plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Vilcanota Valley Rehabilitation and Management Project, is
            to support the Peruvian Government's efforts to enhance
            the environmental and socio-economic sustainability of
            historical, cultural, and ecological assets in the Vilcanota
            Valley, including the historical sanctuary of Machu Picchu
            (HSMP) and the Sacred Valley of the Incas. This will involve
            the preparation and execution of minor infrastructure works,
            capacity building and institutional strengthening actions at
            various levels of government, and the undertaking of careful
            studies on key social and environmental issues, with a
            particular emphasis on disaster management and risk
            reduction. This project has been resubmitted to the Board
            for restructuring. Bank safeguard policy OP 4.10, on
            Indigenous Peoples, has been triggered as part of the
            restructuring. As indigenous communities are determined to
            constitute the majority of project beneficiaries, the
            policy's more rigorous standards of stakeholder
            engagement and respect for local cultures will apply to the
            project as a whole. This Summary of the project's
            approach for ensuring compliance with the policy, including
            a detailed overview of the consultation process undertaken
            to date, and arrangements regarding future planned
            consultations, has been disclosed in-country by the Client
            and in InfoShop, according to Bank disclosure requirements.

repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Vilcanota Valley Rehabilitation and
            Management Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Vilcanota Valley Rehabilitation and Management Project, is
            to support the Government's efforts to enhance the
            environmental and socio-economic sustainability of
            historical, cultural, and ecological assets in the Vilcanota
            Valley, including the historical sanctuary of Machu Picchu
            (HSMP) and the Sacred Valley of the Incas. This will require
            infrastructure works, namely access roads, water supply and
            sanitation, and construction of tourist areas requiring
            visitor centers, rehabilitation of archaeological sites, and
            telecommunications centers. This project has been
            resubmitted to the Board for restructuring. This document
            discusses environmental and social management of the
            Restructured Project. The environmental assessment (EA)
            comprises 4 volumes that contain environmental management
            guidelines (V. 1) summarizing the project background;
            guidelines for minor infrastructure works (V. 2) outlining
            the environmental policy framework and legislation, and, the
            proposed mitigation for infrastructure works under
            environmental categories A, B, or C, including basic
            procedural manuals; and, guidelines for the environmental
            assessment on the construction of sanitary landfills (V. 3).
            This document is V. 4 and replaces V. 1. Under the
            Restructured Project, the EA of the Project will be updated
            to reflect changes such as the fact that sanitary landfills
            will not be constructed. Instead there will be a study on
            solid waste options for the Valley. Training programs shall
            be conducted taking into account the socioeconomic
            conditions of local communities. Work safety guidelines are
            included in V. 2.
